articles.title: World Cup 2022 semi-finals: Can Morocco or Croatia shatter glass ceiling against France and Argentina?
articles.description: In 21 editions of the World Cup over 92 years featuring 79 nations, there have been only eight winners and only 13 have made it to the final; Spain were the last to join the elite group of champions in 2010; Follow Argentina vs Croatia and France vs Morocco in our dedicated live blogs
articles.content:
Croatia and Morocco are the surprise guests in the World Cup's final four but, as the Croatians discovered in 2018 and many other long-shot semi-finalists have before them, the two remaining steps to become world champions can be the steepest.

articles.title: CBOT soybeans drop on export concerns, rains in Argentina
articles.description: CHICAGO, Dec 12 (Reuters) - Chicago Board of Trade soybean futures fell 1.5% on Monday, with the market under pressure from weekend rains in Argentina and concerns about slowing demand from China, traders said. * Soymeal futures dropped on a round of profit taking after eight straight days of gains pushed the most-active contract to its highest on a continuous basis since

articles.title: FIFA World Cup 2022: Brazilian Legend Ronaldo Backing France to Defend Title
articles.description: Ronaldo will not be rooting for the South American arch-rivals Argentina and has been impressed by the French outfit, stating that they have a solid defence, midfield and attack
articles.content:
Former Brazil star Ronaldo says he cannot get behind his country’s great sporting rivals Argentina at the World Cup, and backs France as “big favourites" to retain their title.

articles.title: Washington Post corrects op-ed about no black players on Argentina soccer team
articles.description: The Washington Post has issued a correction to an op-ed piece which laments the fact that Argentina's national soccer team has no black players.
articles.content:
The Washington Post was forced to issue a correction to an op-ed piece that lamented the absence of black players on Argentina’s national soccer team — even though the black population of the South American country is less than 1%.
